name: 4,4-bis(dimethylamino)benzophenone
Reason: 4,4-Bis(dimethylamino)benzophenone has a melting point influenced by functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 4,4-bis(dimethylamino)benzophenone, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the dimethylamino group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, further raising the melting point by about +20°C.
